designations.source: A review of the Hemiptera of Great Britain: The Aquatic and Semi-aquatic Bugs
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national status of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs using IUCN methodology for assessing threat. It covers all species of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs (Heteroptera) in Great Britain, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and non-native species. A.A. Cook November 2015.
designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: Taxa which are neither threatened nor near threatened.
designations.comments: First recorded on the North Norfolk coast at Snettisham in 2005 (Brooke, 2005) and since then at other sites in Bedfordshire, Lincolnshire, Northamptonshire, Leicestershire & Sussex. S. iactans may have been present in the country for some time before 2005 - it was found in a sample from the Norfolk Broads collected in 2004 that was re-examined in the light of recent discoveries (Sheila Brooke, pers. comm.). As a presumed recent colonist the status NA could be given - but because it is very likely that its establishment and fairly rapid spread in England represents a natural extension of range it is designated as LC and considered an established 'native'.
